Great. So one of the questions
that I'm really interested in my
research is how we can allow agents to
learn a breadth of skills

in the real world? And by agents I mean actual
physical robots in the world.

So here are some videos of some
of the things that we've had robots do in my research lab.

In this case, actually,
I'm holding the block here. The robot learned how to
place the sorting cube into the corresponding hole.

We've also looked
at scenarios where we want to have the
robot be able to watch a video of a human do something
and have the robot figure out

how to solve the task. And also see if robots can
figure out how to use tools

in order to accomplish
tasks as well. And I'm really fascinated
by problems like this

because robots I think can teach
us things about intelligence.

This might sound
a little bit funny because robots aren't
intelligent themselves, but robots are faced
with the real world.

They have to be
able to generalize across different tasks and
across different environments in order to be useful.

They need some sort of
common sense understanding in order to perform well. And also supervision can't
really be taken for granted.

You have a robot like
in a physical space and it's not even really clear
what the supervision should be.

You're not given just a
labeled data set, for example. And I think that all
these sorts of things

make it a really fascinating
problem because a lot of these are like the things
that humans are faced with when they're
trying to learn and become

more intelligent. And so first I'll start by
telling a little bit of story

from here, which is that
at the beginning of my PhD, there was a project
that was trying

to see how robots can learn. And I was kind of sitting
in kind of an area

right next to this robot. I was watching it learn like in. This case, it's trying to
learn how to assemble the toy

plane, essentially. It's trying to learn how to
place the wheels into the toy plane.

And I think it's
really fascinating because the robot
is actually learning through trial and error
how to solve the task. At the very beginning,
it knew nothing

about how to solve the task. And by the end, it
actually becomes quite proficient at solving the task.

That said, there was
a bit of a catch, which is that the robot
had its eyes closed the whole entire time. And it was just doing
this purely based

on feel, essentially. And from there, a kind of pretty
natural next step is, well,

can it actually also
learn how to see as well as learn how to actually
move its arms as well? And so that's one of
the first projects

I did during my PhD
was trying to see, can we have the robot learn
through trial and error-- both learning a
perception system,

essentially learning
a neural network that takes as input images from
the robot's camera and outputs torque supplied to
the robot's joints

in order to solve the task? And you can see at the beginning
the robot was kind of just moving his arm around randomly.

And over time, it's learning
not just how to move its arm, but also how to
kind of figure out

where the block is so
that it can put the block into the corresponding hole.

And so you can see
the final policy here

where I'm kind of holding
the block out for the robot and the robot's point of
view is on the bottom right.

And what was pretty exciting
about this algorithm wasn't that the robot
learned this one skill, but that the robot could learn
lots of different skills.

So it could use the
same exact algorithm to learn something like
putting the claw of a toy

hammer underneath a nail
and like screwing a cap on to a bottle, for example.

And also use a very
similar algorithm to use a spatula to lift
an object into a bowl.

So this may seem like a
little bit of a tangent. Overall, we were really excited
about this sort of approach.

But there was kind of a
pretty huge catch with all of this, which is that the
robot, in this case, what it

learned wasn't how to use
spatulas to lift objects into bowls, it had learned
how to use that spatula

to lift that object
into that bowl. And if you gave the
robot a different spatula or asked it to do something
else or gave it a different bowl

or changed the
environment, the robot wouldn't be able
to solve the task.

And this is a problem
because, ultimately, we want robots to be able to
do lots of different tasks and not just one
very narrow skill.

And so in many ways,
this is the motivation in my mind behind
trying to build systems that are
more general and that

can do many different tasks. So around the same
time people also use the same algorithm
to do other skills

like hitting a puck into a
goal, like opening a door, like throwing an
object to hit a target. And around the same time, people
are also developing approaches

for playing games like Atari
or Go or learning how to walk. But in all of these
cases they were

learning one task
in one environment starting from scratch. Now you might say, OK, I know
how to solve this problem,

we just need to give
the robot more spatulas and then it'll learn how to do
the task with many spatulas.

And we need to
give it more tasks and it'll learn
that and so forth. But there's also
a catch with that

which is that if you look
behind the scenes and a lot of these learning
processes, in many cases

it looks something like this
where the robot tries the task and then the environment
needs to kind of be

reset to some initial state. And then the robot tries
the task again and so forth.

And one of the things you
might notice here this is my friend, Yevgen.
And Yevgen is doing more work than the robot is doing.

And this is kind of silly. Like we want robots to
be able to kind of learn by themselves autonomously. And in this way,
actually, Yevgen

is like doing a lot of the
work to do this learning process rather than the robot.

It's not practical to
collect a lot of data across a lot of different
tasks in this way. And so we need new
techniques in order

to allow robots
and other systems to learn many different tasks
rather than just one task.

So I've talked about this a
lot in the context of robotics, but this isn't just a problem
in robotics and reinforcement

learning. If we look at a lot of the kind
of state of the art machine learning systems,
a lot of them are specialized for one individual
task like translating

between one language pair
or recognizing speech or detecting certain objects.

So these are often in
more diverse settings, but they're still one
task starting from scratch with pretty detailed
supervision.

And I'll refer to
all these systems as sort of specialists
in the sense that they're solving
just a single task.

Ultimately, we want systems
maybe to be a little bit more like humans-- that are
more like generalists that

can do lots of different
things and learn in richer worlds than
the kinds of robots

that I was showing before.  And then one last note on
this in terms of my motivation

is that I think that if you
look at a system like AlphaGo and a lot of the reinforcement
learning systems that I showed

before, they're somewhat
analogous to essentially teaching a baby on
day one to play Go.

And from that standpoint,
it's actually really silly to train systems specialized
for a single task.

It's kind of ridiculous
just to think that you can learn
a single task really well without learning about
other aspects of the world

and so forth. And with that, Karol
will come and talk

about a little
bit more about why he cares about multi-task
learning and meta-learning. Thank you, Chelsea.

All right. So in my PhD, I was
also working on robots.

And I was working
on-- initially, I was working more on classical
robotic pipelines where we have a perception system
that has to perceive the world

and then the robot has
to look at the output of that perception system and
do something in that world.

And when I was working on it,
I realized that it's actually really, really hard. So if perception system
fails at some point,

and it fails in a way that
the robot doesn't really know what to do with it, the
whole system breaks apart.

And at that point
during my PhD, I attended a talk by
Sergey Levin, who

is now a professor
at Berkeley, who started talking
about similar things

that Chelsea just talked
about, about robots that learn through deep neural
networks, that learn end to end a whole bunch
of different tasks.

And that interact
with the environment and optimize the entire pipeline
and learn how to do things.

And I got really
inspired by that so I changed the
topic of my PhD and I started working on deep
reinforcement learning instead.

And right now,
what really excites me is that I really want to see
how the recipe that has worked

in other fields, such
as computer vision or language, the recipe where
we apply modern machine learning

methods to a field and it
is able to do really, really well in that field, how can
we apply a similar recipe

to robotics? So if we look at that recipe,
it consists of two things.

So first, we need a lot of data. For instance, the size of the
ImageNet, a million images,

so that we have enough data
to optimize our neural net. Or in natural
language processing,
maybe we need all of Wikipedia. Anyway, we need a lot of data.

And then we need
expressive, capable models that will be able to
digest all of this data.

So in computer vision,
traditionally, these have been convolutional
neural nets. And in language
processing, these

have been mostly
transformers now being applied also
to computer vision and to many other domains.

So if we just were
to look at this and see what would
it take to apply

the same recipe for
robotics, in terms of expressive, capable models,
it's actually fairly easy.

We use very similar libraries. We can look at PyTorch or
TensorFlow or anything else. Take the best model
that was applied

to let's say, natural
language processing and just apply it to robots. But when it comes to data,
it's a little more tricky.

We can just go on the
internet and download-- scrape off a whole
bunch of robotic data

that is high quality where
robots do a lot of things. But actually, I think
it's a little bit more

nuanced than that. And with a lot of
data, if we look at some of the results in
reinforcement learning,

for instance, we actually
do have a lot of data. So here is one example
of the work from OpenAI,

of a robot learning how to
operate this little cube here.

And actually, the
amount of experience that they had to
collect in simulation was equivalent to 100 years.

And we've seen many
reinforcement learning, robotic reinforcement
learning experiments, that we actually do have a
lot of data for these tasks.

However, if we were to
double the size of the data, of the data set, we would
see that at some point

the performance
starts to plateau and we don't really see
much benefit in providing more data to the robot.

The robot already
mastered the task or learned as much as
it could from that data set, extracted all
the information.

And even if we were to
pour much, much more data, the robot is not really
going to improve. It's not going to learn
more about the world.

However, if we look at
supervised learning, at the data set
such as ImageNet,

if we were to double the
size of that data set, I would bet that the algorithm
would actually get better.

And the reason for this is that
ImageNet is much more diverse. ImageNet has many different
categories, not just

taken by different
people and so on. And I believe that's what
we need for robots as well.

We need to have data sets that
are multi-task data sets, that

consists of multiple robots
in many different environments doing different things.

So here, I should be a
little bit more precise and say that we don't
just need a lot of data, but we need a lot of
diverse multi-task data.

And in this course
we'll talk about what are the challenges
associated with that. But also once we have
that data, how can

we utilize it best to
learn multi-task policies so that robots can learn how
to do many different things

and how they can discover
structure between these tasks so that learning each
task is more efficient.

And this is why I'm really
excited about multi-task RL and RL and all these things.

So this is the reason
that I usually give people

why to work in these things,
but there is actually the real reason that I want
to reveal to you right now.

All right. I'll hand it over to Chelsea. Thanks. Great, so, that was kind of
the perspective from robotics

and a lot of the research
that I do and that Karol does. But beyond robotics
and beyond trying

to build more general purpose

these kinds of topics.

So first, why should
we care in particular about deep multi-task
and meta-learning?

Like Karol alluded to,
before deep learning, there were these more kind
of hand-designed pipelines

for building AI systems. And so for example, a system
like this uses something

like these hog features that
are hand-designed to try to pick out different kinds
of features in an image.

And then you would do some
sort of deformable part model on top of that feature, which
is another hand-designed tool.

And then maybe you do
a tiny bit of learning on top of that with an SVM. And with modern computer
vision, this kind of

changed the way that people
approach the problem. And instead of trying to
hand-design different aspects of a pipeline, they
instead would just

learn everything in this end
to end fashion from data. And the reason why this recipe
or this kind of second approach

is really exciting
is that it allows us to be able to handle
unstructured inputs.

It means that we
can handle things like pixels, language,
sensor readings directly rather than having
to assume that we have access

to some more structured
features that are extracted from these
more unstructured inputs.

And this means that we don't
need hand-designed features, we don't need as much
domain knowledge as well. And as a result,
these approaches

are actually often
much more applicable than approaches that require
very detailed domain knowledge.

And beyond not requiring
domain knowledge, they also work really well. So if you look at
ImageNet performance

over multiple
different years, you see there's a little bit of a
phase transition between kind

of right here basically in 2012. And that was AlexNet. And this was essentially really
the first deep neural network

that was successful in
being applied to the image that data set and really led
to this whole phase transition

and led to much
better performance. And afterwards, everything
after here is neural networks.

It's not just true
in computer vision, also in machine translation.

This paper by Google
showed that you can apply deep neural networks
to machine translation.

And if you look at the
performance differences between a kind of a

use in this class, you're given data on a
set of previous tasks

and your goal is to learn a
new task more quickly or more proficiently. And this is an
important distinction

because in the multi-task
learning problem, you aren't necessarily trying
to be able to kind of adapt or learn something

what you are given, whereas in

adapt to a new task.
